name: eastgully
approach: King Ravine Trail to Great Gully Trail

name: great gully lower
approach: Short steep approach from Castle Trailhead.
hazards: Rockfall risk late season; cornice hazard

name: iced out
approach: Long approach; requires alpine navigation and experience.

name: the muffin
approach: Approach from Gulf Trailhead; short steep skin.

name: narrow gully
approach: Approach from Gulf Trailhead; short steep skin.

name: great gully
approach: Approach from Gulf Trailhead; short steep skin.

name: west gully
approach: Approach from Gulf Trailhead; short steep skin.

name: Baby Sister
approach: Approach via Castle Trail. Continue past the upper drainage fork and skin into the lower apron beneath the Sisters. Line begins at the leftmost branch.
hazards: Narrow constriction, ice bulges in midwinter, overhead snow loaded from Castle Ridge.
notes: Hand-drawn prototype geometry. Replace with survey or GPS track before production.

name: Middle Sister
approach: Follow the Castle Trail to the main drainage. Skin into the gully center; this line splits center-left between Baby and South Sister.
hazards: Runneled midsection, potential rockfall late season, confined terrain.
notes: Hand-drawn prototype geometry. Replace with more precise track before publishing.

name: South Sister
approach: Skin up Castle Trail and head into the bowl. South Sister is the lower-angle sibling but still sustained.
hazards: Midwinter ice, wind slab loaded from Adams' shoulder, terrain trap apron.

name: North Sister
approach: Skin up Castle Trail to the central basin then trend skier’s right. North Sister has the longest and most continuous fall line.
hazards: Steeper upper rollovers, cross-loaded pockets, exposure near the top funnel.
notes: Prototype geometry imported from manual trace.

name: abby's way
approach: Approach via Jefferson Loop Trail to the base of the headwall.
hazards: Steep terrain, hidden rocks, avalanche risk.

name: jefferson headwall
approach: Approach from Jefferson Loop Trail to the north couloir base.
